tickets.description:
Hi,

This is the calibration data for two Nikon lenses on crop factor 1 (Nikon D600 body):
  - Nikon 50mm f/1.4G AFS
  - Nikon 20mm f/2.8 AIS (manual focus version of the Nikon 20mm f/2.8 D AF)

The 50mm was not in the library.

For the 20mm lens, there's an entry for "Nikon 20mm f/2.8 D AF" (both are optically equivalent) but only for 1.5 crop factor.

I calibrated the lens distortion manually with Hugin, and tca with tca_correct.

Cheers!
Nicolas

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: Thank you for your contribution!  Did you put control points on straight lines in Hugin, or did you do a 360° panorama?
posts.subject: #1 Nikon 50mm 1.4G AFS and 20mm 2.8AIS

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: According to <http://wilson.bronger.org/lensfun_coverage.html>, there is already the 50mm in the database, but with a bigger crop factor, so your contribution is welcomed.
posts.subject: #1 Nikon 50mm 1.4G AFS and 20mm 2.8AIS

posts.author: nlann
posts.text:
I took raw photos of a skyscraper and manually added control points on straight lines. Hugin displays only 3 or 4 digits, so I took the parameters directly from inside the .pto file.

I've tested the corrected distortion on different images. After correction in Darktable, I don't see any more distortion, including in the corners. So for my lenses, the correction is perfect.

The TCA correction is also good, but not perfect on the 20mm lens at 100% or 200%. I'm not sure yet if it's a problem with ptlens model or darktable interpolation/demosaicing...

I'm also working on the vignetting correction, but no good results so far.
posts.subject: #1 Nikon 50mm 1.4G AFS and 20mm 2.8AIS

posts.author: nlann
posts.text:
It must be a very recent addition, I don't have it in the source I got on
05/04. I will update, thanks.
posts.subject: #1 Nikon 50mm 1.4G AFS and 20mm 2.8AIS

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: As for the vignetting correction, I recommend my method at <http://wilson.bronger.org/lens_calibration_tutorial/#id3>.
posts.subject: #1 Nikon 50mm 1.4G AFS and 20mm 2.8AIS

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: I pushed your contributions to the git master and close this ticket now.  Thank you again!

posts.author: bronger
posts.text:
Thank you for your efforts, but I don't think using this data is the way to go.  The Coolpix S3300 already corrects the JPEGs, and it does a very good job at it -- with your calibration, you rather check the straightness of the buildings than the behaviour of the lens.  So, just live with the JPEGs, they are really good.

That said, this info is valuable.  I will include a data set in Lensfun saying that this camera does already the correction.  Besides, it makes projection changes possible.

tickets.summary: Move aspect-ratio and cropfactor into <calibration> tag
tickets.description:
Proposal from the mailing list:
https://sourceforge.net/p/lensfun/mailman/message/33186260/

We could move the aspect ratio and crop factor into the calibration tag and allow several calibration sections per lens. This could solve the problems of multiple lens entries for different crop factors or aspect ratios and even for RAW/JPEG.

For example:

    <lens>
        ...
        <calibration aspect-ratio="4:3" cropfactor="1.536" RAW="true">
            <distortion ...>
            ...
        </calibration>
        <calibration aspect-ratio="4:3" cropfactor="1.0" RAW="true">
            <distortion ...>
            ...
        </calibration>
    </lens>

tickets.description: I am at final days of my master thesis. I use a Canon EF-S 10-22mm f/3.5-4.5 USM lens with an EOS 500D to capture a tiled display wall trying to measure the color variation between the screens. Since the wall is quite large, the measurement is strongly affected by the vignetting. I used Canons proprietary tools for vignette correction, but i would like to do that automatically. I stumbled upon lensfun which seems to be able to do exactly what i need, but it is missing the vignette correction data for that lens. Since other data for the lens is already available, should i try to use that to generate vignette correction data or should i start from scratch with that lens?

posts.author: bronger
posts.text:
You cannot use this setup for vignette measurements.  Instead, please follow the steps described in http://wilson.bronger.org/lens_calibration_tutorial/#id3 and upload the images at <http://wilson.bronger.org/calibration>.  But first make sure that you can use the data in a way which is suitable for you.

If you have further questions, please use out mailing list or contact me directly.
posts.subject: #31 Canon EF-S 10-22mm f/3.5-4.5 USM (Vignetting)

tickets.summary: Request inclusion+documentation  of lenstool in tarball
tickets.description:
I've posted about this on the mailing list, but since I'm now going to ask for a "feature request", I assume that this is "official channels". Please forgive me if I'm missing something obvious. Right now, if I shoot 100 or 200 photos in a day, and they require lensfun correction like http://www.dpreview.com/forums/post/51970815 it has to be done manually 100 or 200 times...

* load CR2 file in GIMP and select OK
* go to "Filters ==> enhancement" in GIMP, and select gimp-lensfun
* click OK (it seems to read the Exif data correctly by default)
* repeat 100 or 200 times (painfull)

Lenstool http://lensfun.sourceforge.net/manual/lenstool_8cpp-example.html looks like it might be what I need to do it at the command line. Can you provide documentation/makefile/whatever to build lenstool as part of the lensfun library tarball? And also a short example of how to use it, e.g. something like...

lenstool input_file output_file parm1 parm2 parm3

I have the perl "exiftool" utility installed, which can read EXIF data from the raw file, for use by lenstool. I'm not a programmer, but I can compile a program, given instructions. My main worry is that the latest lensfun on Gentoo linux is 0.3.0 and the lenstool code is for 0.3.1.0. Are they compatable?

tickets.description: I'm attaching the distortion calibration I generated for my Olympus TG-4.  As the lens doesn't seem to have changed since the TG-1, there's a good chance these parameters will also work for the TG-1, TG-2, and TG-3.

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: Thank you for the contribution!  I have two questions:  How did you get this data?  Actually, Hugin never overcorrects.  Where does the FOV come from?
posts.subject: #35 Olympus TG-4

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: - **assigned_to**: Torsten Bronger
posts.subject: #35 Olympus TG-4

posts.author: ralfbrown
posts.text:
I used the 'calibrate_lens_gui' from Hugin 2013.0.0.0d404a7088e6
(Mageia Linux 4, haven't had time to upgrade to Mageia 5 since it was
released in mid-June).  The calibration images were of the brick wall
of a building that has a pedestrian bridge running along-side.  I know
the docs say not to use that, but it seems the biggest issue is that
the program finds shorter line segments rather than lines going all
the way across the image.  There's a building downtown that would make
a perfect target (especially if there were a way to shoot it from
about 50 feet off the ground), but I don't get downtown more than once
every year to two....

I double-checked the calibration in darktable, testing for
straightness of lines.  All focal lengths were very good except for
9mm, which wound up bowed almost exactly the same amount in the
opposite direction.  Cut a/b/c values in half, check again, and voila,
straight lines.  I'm attaching a reduced-resolution version of the 9mm
image.

FOV values are what 'calibrate_lens_gui' spit out.

   Ralf

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: I'm sure the distortion data for the 100-400mm at 250mm is a slip.  Erik, could you check whether you have ptlens data for this lens and focal length?  Thank you very much!  (Until I hear from you, I simply remove this focal length.)
posts.subject: #47 Four Cannon EF zooms

posts.author: quister
posts.text:
Hi Torsten,

Sorry for the delay, I'd been on holday.

That is indeed odd. I've just gone digging back into the files which created these values. Noticed that in the lenses.txt in which I'd pasted the distortion values from Hugin, the 250mm line is the only one in which a value is expressed in exponential notation:

~~~
# For suggestions for <maker> and <mount> see <http://goo.gl/BSARX>.
# <aspect-ratio> is optional and by default 3:2.
# Omit <type> for rectilinear lenses.

EF100-400mm f/4.5-5.6L IS USM: Canon, Canon EF, 1
distortion(100.0mm) = 0.00025675727, -0.00086839235, 0
distortion(135.0mm) = 0.00025565499, 0.0023856892, 0
distortion(150.0mm) = -0.00025251856, 0.0041025843, 0
distortion(200.0mm) = -0.00026568272, 0.005564501, 0
distortion(250.0mm) = -7.6806451e-05, 0.0056209899, 0
distortion(300.0mm) = 0.00028689712, 0.0053289804, 0
distortion(350.0mm) = -0.00021378004, 0.0064708104, 0
distortion(400.0mm) = 0.00035256656, 0.0059394729, 0
~~~

So I can only assume that something went off the rails due to that? I don't recall, as it's been so long since I created these files.. Does the calibrate.py script then generate the final XML? 

Either way, this line is what the 250mm distortion values should have been:

            <distortion model="ptlens" focal="250" a="-0.000076806451" b="0.0056209899" c="0" />

Sorry for not noticing that!

Cheers,
Erik
posts.subject: #47 Four Cannon EF zooms

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: Ah, thank you for the input!  It is a bug in calibrate.py.  It could not deal with scientific notation.  I fixed that.
posts.subject: #47 Four Cannon EF zooms

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: I also amended the lens profile accordingly.
posts.subject: #47 Four Cannon EF zooms

There isn't a way to convert a k1 v2 value to a k2 version 1 value by any chance? Or what software do you use/should I use to read version 2 format? (windows/linux don't mind). Thanks!!!
posts.subject: #68 New lens: gitup git2

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: The aspect-ratio tag is available also in version 1 of the DB.  So, unless you have a really old Lensfun version, just leave it in and use version="1".
posts.subject: #68 New lens: gitup git2

posts.author: markhale
posts.text: Ok, I'll try it when I get home later.
posts.subject: #68 New lens: gitup git2

posts.author: markhale
posts.text: So, I dl-ed and built lensfun 0.3.2, and linked it to darktable, and ran lensfun-update-data that dl-ed a version=1 actioncams.xml with the gitup entry including aspect-ratio into .local. Ran on darktable and tried the fisheye correction - still only see a slight correction to the curvature. I'm doing this with jpgs if that has any bearings.
posts.subject: #68 New lens: gitup git2

posts.author: markhale
posts.text: I've worked out where I was going wrong. The target geometry in darktable had defaulted to thoby fisheye, once I had set it to rectilinear my photos straightened up nicely! In hugin, I noticed I had both target and source geometry set to rectilinear. Once I changed source to equisolid, things looked better there too. A quick play with the optimizer and I got a b/k1 of around 0.016, close to yours, so I knew I was now doing it right. Many thanks!!!
posts.subject: #68 New lens: gitup git2

posts.author: bronger
posts.text:

posts.subject: #68 New lens: gitup git2

posts.text: You are welcome.  The “thoby problem” is due to a binary incompatibility between Lensfun versions.  Actually, DT needs to be re-compiled.  But nobody has reported crashes so far, only the thoby problem, and this is annoying but harmless.

tickets.summary: distortion and tca parameters Sigma 28-70mm F2.8 AF
tickets.description:
Hi, I started to use ACDSee Ultimate 10 for developing my photos. It uses the lensfun database for lens correction tools, but I noticed that some of my rather old lenses are not supported. 
Thus, I followed http://lensfun.sourceforge.net/calibration/ to determine distortion and tca parameters for my Sigma 28-70mm F2.8 AF lens (>20 years old) with a new Sony Alpha 7 Mark II and mount adapter LA-EA4 using Hugin (v. 2016.2.0.be8da0221960 built by Thomas). The xml entry including the parameters should look like this:

~~~
<lens>
    <maker>Sigma</maker>
    <model>Sigma 28-70mm F2.8 AF</model>
    <mount>Minolta A</mount>
    <cropfactor>1.0</cropfactor>
    <calibration>
	    <!-- Taken with Sony A7II and mount adapter LA-EA4 -->
        <distortion model="ptlens" focal="28" a="0.0146" b="-0.0486" c="0.005"/>
        <distortion model="ptlens" focal="35" a="0.0061" b="-0.0223" c="0.0020"/>
		<distortion model="ptlens" focal="50" a="-0.0004" b="0.0015" c="-0.0043"/>
        <distortion model="ptlens" focal="70" a="0.0028" b="-0.0045" c="0.0071"/>
        <tca model="ptlens" focal="28" ar="0.00038" br="-0.00258" cr="0.00347" vr="0.99960" ab="-0.000013" bb="0.00050" cb="-0.00045" vb="0.99984"/>
		<tca model="ptlens" focal="35" ar="-0.00042" br="0.00051" cr="0.00019" vr="1.00032" ab="-0.000015" bb="0.00026" cb="-0.00015" vb="0.99979"/>
		<tca model="ptlens" focal="50" ar="0.00002" br="-0.00018" cr="0.00017" vr="1.00012" ab="-0.000090" bb="0.00035" cb="-0.00027" vb="0.99993"/>
		<tca model="ptlens" focal="70" ar="-0.00009" br="0.00026" cr="-0.00023" vr="0.99996" ab="-0.000053" bb="0.00014" cb="-0.00006" vb="0.99995"/>			
    </calibration>
</lens>
~~~

Is this correct, and can I send parameters for other lense this way?
Could you  include it in the database?

Thanks and best regards,
Christoph

posts.author: bronger
posts.text:
Thank you for the data!  I have three questions:

* I changed “Minolta A” to “Minolta AF”.  Okay?
* Do you know for which other moints this lens was available?
* Lensfun's TCA correction only knows the parameters “br”, “cr”, “vr”, “bb”, “cb”, and “vb”.  Your fit included the “a” parameters.  This doesn't work I think.

tickets.summary: Add support for Canon EF-M 15-45mm f/3.5-6.3 IS STM
tickets.description:
Support for this lens is currently missing.

Attached is the xml-file with my calibration data.

I'm not sure about the naming.  "EF-M15-45mm f/3.5-6.3 IS STM" was generated by calibrate.py based on the exif-information:

exiv2 -pt M3I_0236.CR2 | grep -ai lens

Exif.CanonCs.LensType                        Short       1  Canon EF-M 15-45mm f/3.5-6.3 IS STM
Exif.CanonCs.Lens                            Short       3  15.0 - 45.0 mm
Exif.Photo.LensSpecification                 Rational    4  15/1 45/1 0/1 0/1
Exif.Photo.LensModel                         Ascii      29  EF-M15-45mm f/3.5-6.3 IS STM
Exif.Photo.LensSerialNumber                  Ascii      11  000001e2b9

But for auto-applying the lens correction in darktable I have to use

<model>Canon EF-M 15-45mm f/3.5-6.3 IS STM</model>

No clue what the correct approach is.

I've tested the file with darktable. In some cases TCA correction is better with the automatic "Chromatic abberation" module than with the generated calibration data. Worse results when using both modules.

The corrected jpegs generated from RAW were compared to the OOC jpegs and I think they hold up OK.

Not sure about the gnuplot graphs: there are some "streaks" of data points below the main curve - is this normal?

Regards,
Oliver

tickets.description:
I followed [these](http://lensfun.sourceforge.net/development/) instructions on Ubuntu 17.04. Works great until you try to compile Darktable.

Darktable builds but the lens module is not there. Darktable 2.2.3 complains in the terminal about not finding the lensfun module. 2.2.4 is even more vague, it only complains if you try to open a picture which (on a previous version of Darktable) uses the lensfun module.

Long story short it is an easy fix. Run ldconfig after installing darktable. Then build Darktable. This might be obvious to the more seasoned linux user but not to me (it cost me a few hours to figure it out). You might want to include it at the end of the instructions to install Lensfun from source.

tickets.summary: CA correction matching according to aperture
tickets.description:
Currently lensfun chooses CA correction only by focal length, however CA on some lenses is also dependent on aperture value. I.e. 

http://www.lenstip.com/upload2/169422_aber.png

http://www.lenstip.com/upload3/3699_aberracja_11.jpg

http://www.lenstip.com/upload3/4192_aberracja_11.jpg

As of now, it is impossible to correct CA for more than one aperture value, because profile can contain only single TCA entry per any given focal length. 

I ask to expand matching of CA corrections so it would take aperture value into account too.

posts.author: computerfreaked
posts.text:
I am by far no expert on this but there are 2 different kinds of CA. LCA and TCA.

TCA is independant of aperture and can be more or less corrected in software. Hence no aperture selection is needed for correction.

LCA is aperture dependant but can not be corrected in software as far as i know.

https://photographylife.com/what-is-chromatic-aberration/
posts.subject: #88 CA correction matching according to aperture

posts.author: bronger
posts.text:
The dependence of TCA on aperture is very weak and beyond Lensfun's scope.  Also note that such an expansion not only means much more complex code (instead of one-dimension interpolation, two-dimensional interpolation would be necessary) but also much more difficulty to create correction data for every lens.

Besides, I second Computerfreaked's concern that LCA may be mixed up with TCA in your images.
posts.subject: #88 CA correction matching according to aperture

posts.author: bronger
posts.text:
- **status**: open --> wont-fix
- **assigned_to**: Torsten Bronger
posts.subject: #88 CA correction matching according to aperture

tickets.summary: Canon FDn 200mm F4 new lens data
tickets.description:
Attached are the corrections I calculated using calibrate.py. It seems the lens is quite affected by LCA at F4 but there is nothing we can do here.

The Canon FD(n) lenses seem to have a bit of a naming issue in Lensfun. Some are called "Canon Lens FDn" others simply "Canon FDn". Currently there are only 3 listed as far as I can see:

- Canon Lens FDn 24mm 1:2.8
- Canon FDn 50mm 1:1.4
- Canon Lens FDn 50mm 1:1.8

I think the word Lens doesn't add anything here. There is no EXIF match possible since all FD(n) lenses have no electronic contacts for EXIF info as far as I know so the <model> tags can be anything you want. I therefore took the liberty of naming it Canon FDn 200mm 1:4.

posts.author: computerfreaked

tickets.summary: Vignetting for 2 Lumix G Vario lenses
tickets.description:
Hi, I've done the simple vignetting calibration (focusing to infinity) for these lenses:

LUMIX G VARIO 12-32/F3.5-5.6  : Panasonic, Micro 4/3 System, 2, 4:3
LUMIX G VARIO 35-100/F4.0-5.6: Panasonic, Micro 4/3 System, 2, 4:3

It's the first time I tried that, so please do a sanity check on my values. I used a milky glass and put the camera underneath it pointing at the ceiling lamp (ca 2 meters above). The camera was handheld with lens pushing against the glass plate. Lens+Sensor image stabilization was on (no digital stabilization).

The tca and distortion are taken from the existing DB entries.

I used the calibration script from Windows, and it needed a major rearranging: when using multiprocessing on Windows, you need to move most of the "effective" code into `if __name__ == "__main__":`, but leave the function/class definitions outside. This is something that can be done quite easily, but I understand it'd affect readability of the script, when the functions are moved away from the places where they are used. There's also a system program called convert.exe which serves for converting FAT partitions to NTFS, and the calibration script is trying to call this one instead of the ImageMagick executable. Quite dangerous :) If you'd be interested in seeing the working script, I can share it.

posts.author: bronger
posts.text:
Thank you, I included your data!  Pointing towards a lamp is not optimal, however, because it may generate a non-uniform brightness behind the diffuser.

I can also include your calibrate.py enhancements.
posts.subject: #89 Vignetting for 2 Lumix G Vario lenses

tickets.summary: Lens corrections for Sigma 17-70 with Minolta / Sony mount
tickets.description:
The existing Lensfun lens corrections made for the Sigma 17-70mm f/2.8-4.5 DC Macro seem to be made with a Canon. Because this has a smaller image circle (crop factor = 1.611), lensfun does not apply them for the Sony mounts. I therefore created lens corrections for Sony APS-C camera (cropfactor = 1.523)

<lens>
        <maker>Sigma</maker>
        <model>Sigma 17-70mm f/2.8-4.5 DC Macro</model>
        <mount>Minolta AF</mount>
        <focal min="17" max="70"/>

        <calibration>
            <distortion model="ptlens" focal="17" a="0.031263" b="-0.089484" c="0.047399" />
            <distortion model="ptlens" focal="18" a="0.017675" b="-0.048197" c="0.014054" />

posts.text:
I had a look on this page: http://lensfun.sourceforge.net/manual/addcamera.html and followed the instructions.

d = sqrt(23.6^2 x 15.6^2) mm = 28,29 mm
cropfactor = 43.27 / d = 1.5295

usage of exiv2 and a *.RAF image:
Camera make: FUJIFILM
Camera model: X-E3

So the XML entry should look like this:

    <camera>
        <maker>Fujifilm</maker>
        <model>X-E3</model>
        <mount>Fujifilm X</mount>
        <cropfactor>1.53</cropfactor>
    </camera>

The Panasonic Lumix DMC-TZ100 (as currently entered in the lensfun database) has a number of different aliases depending on the area of purchase even though it is the same camera. In Australia it is the TZ110, in Europe I believe it is TZ100 and in the USA is ZS100 and I think TZ101 in Japan. Anyway as present my camera (TZ110) is not recognised by applications using the lensfun database of lens corrections as only TZ100 is present. In some applications there is the ability to set the camera for lens corrections if it is not automatically recognised (e.g. darktable) but in others (e.g. Affinity Photo) this is not possible. Can the Lensfun database please be updated to include the aliases for the TZ100 camera. Thank you.

tickets.description:
I am a new user of RawTherapee and I use a Panasonic GX-7. One of the lenses is the first Panasonic kit zoom: the Lumix G Vario 14-45mm f/3.5-5.6 Asph. Mega OIS.
I discovered that the lensfun distortion profile for this lens is completely wrong, so I calibrated it by myself, with good results.

Here are the relevant rows from mil-panasonic.xml:

    <lens>
        <maker>Panasonic</maker>
        <model>Lumix G Vario 14-45mm f/3.5-5.6 Asph. Mega OIS</model>
        <mount>Micro 4/3 System</mount>
        <cropfactor>2</cropfactor>
        <aspect-ratio>4:3</aspect-ratio>
        <calibration>
            <distortion focal="14" model="ptlens" a="0.025592" b="-0.090127" c="0.015798"/>
            <distortion focal="16" model="ptlens" a="0.01809" b="-0.073058" c="0.022836"/>
            <distortion focal="18" model="ptlens" a="0.012509" b="-0.059775" c="0.024515"/>
            <distortion focal="21" model="ptlens" a="0.007897" b="-0.037455" c="0.009952"/>
            <distortion focal="24" model="ptlens" a="0.003023" b="-0.018247" c="-0.004231"/>
            <distortion focal="26" model="ptlens" a="0.003449" b="-0.019627" c="0.003703"/>
            <distortion focal="30" model="ptlens" a="0.010133" b="-0.036009" c="0.020535"/>
            <distortion focal="34" model="ptlens" a="-0.002539" b="0.00401" c="-0.012615"/>
            <distortion focal="37" model="ptlens" a="0.000292" b="-0.002104" c="-0.005641"/>
            <distortion focal="40" model="ptlens" a="-0.003796" b="0.009287" c="-0.011851"/>
            <distortion focal="45" model="ptlens" a="-0,000847" b="0,003645" c="-0,008538"/>

I hope that the format of the data is good for you, but I can send you the whole file or whatever you need.

I realize that this is a rather old lens, but probably there are other users around and at the moment the distortion correction is really awful.

posts.text: There are multiple crop factors for several of the lens profiles. Each profile should have *one* crop factor, which is the one for the camera that was used to profile the lens (it doesn't matter what format the lens was intended for).

posts.author: bronger
posts.text:
@robert: Please provide further information so that we can include your data:

Which camera was used?  A 6D Mark I cannot be used for Touit or XF mount lenses.

As junkyardsparkle has already pointed out, there must be only one cropfactor per calibration.  Besides, cropfactor “1” for an XF lens is probably incorrect.  So, which cropfactor was used for

- Touit 1.8/32
- Touit 2.8/12
- Fujifilm XF80mmF2.8

Thank you!

tickets.summary: Calibration data for Panasnic LX15/LX10 update
tickets.description:
The profile for Panasonic LX15/LX10 fixed lens is commented with  "The images used may have been from a decentered copy, profile could probably be improved". Indeed I am  not satisfied by the values, so I made another calibration (attached).

Notes :

1) I calibrated for all "steps" of the "step zoom" of the camera.

2) Some other values from the continuous zoom mode, which were present in previous data, are kept. I wonder if it is a good practice since the author indicated that they are potentially bugged in the comments.  

3) I have high confidence in the distortion data: they were cross checked with several photographs from my library and everything looks fine.

4) TCA data might be improved: I am not very confortable with the process and I used only one sample per measure. Activating TCA correction with this profile slightly improve my images though, so I suppose that the values are not bad, even if they might be better.

5) I added French translation for the model of the lens

6) I changed maker name of the fixed lens, since it is a LEICA DC VARIO-SUMMILUX 1:1.4-2.8/8.8-26.4 ASPH

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text: - **status**: open --> implemented

tickets.description: Attached patch corrects implementation of exported lf_db_read_timestamp function. This function will be useful for darktable.

posts.author: seebk
posts.text:
Thanks for your patch.
What kind of issues did you have in Darktable with the current lf_db_read_timestamp() function? lfDatabase::ReadTimestamp is static and so I think the current implementation of the C-wrapper would be correct...
posts.subject: #146 lf_db_read_timestamp wrong function signature

posts.author: parafin
posts.text: There is a mismatch between prototype in header and actual implementation, so currently it's not possible to use lf_db_read_timestamp function at all - you will get undefined symbol error during linking. tickets.summary: Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)
tickets.description: Please add the attached lens data to the lensfun data base.

posts.author: maciejpatelczyk
posts.text: PDF files with the graphs for both lenses.
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text: Nice graphs... in practice, the problem with vignetting calibration isn't so much the fitting to the input images, but rather that sometimes (more so with wider lenses in my experience) the diffuser-on-lens images don't create an accurate model of real-world vignetting behavior. Were you able to check the results on some evenly-lit real-world images for possible over-correction, by any chance?
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

posts.author: maciejpatelczyk
posts.text: Sure, I will. I will shoot it RAW+JPEG and check it. Just give ma a few days.
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

posts.author: maciejpatelczyk
posts.text:
Easier said than done.  In my neighborhood I have found fresh grey mineral plaster on one small building which seemed to be perfect candidate to check the result. The elevation is quite uniform and was well lid (northen side and today there was a fog).
I shot it on 1.5m distance with focus on the wall. There vignietting correction visually are correct. I'm unable to find overcorrections. **L** variations between corners are not greater than 5 (but in uncorrected image they also occur so the wall was not evenly lid after all).
However...
PanaLeicas are rather known for theirs variations in image quality (see: [Lens rental on 25mm](https://www.lensrentals.com/blog/2018/01/finally-some-m43-mtf-testing-25mm-prime-lens-comparison/) or [LensTip on 15mm vignetting](https://www.lenstip.com/412.8-Lens_review-Panasonic_Leica_DG_Summilux_15_mm_f_1.7_ASPH_Vignetting.html) or [LensTip on 20mm vigetting](https://www.lenstip.com/269.8-Lens_review-Panasonic_G_20_mm_f_1.7_ASPH._Vignetting.html). My point is that I do not know my starting position.
I will shoot more RAW+JPG images (with vignetting corrected in body) and compare the results.
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text:
Yes, it's surprisingly difficult to find large, evenly illuminated featureless surfaces... but for checking the corrections you just need a shot that would show if there's visible lightening at the edges of the frame. Clear sky will usually work for this, particularly if the image is viewed at a very small size, which makes it easier to visually notice stuff like that. If a sky shot with the lens set to minimum focus distance doesn't show edge lightening visually, the correction is probably ok.

Unfortunately, for the internally-focusing Micro 4/3 lenses I've tested myself, the vignetting changes substantially between close focus and infinity, with infinity being the worst case. This means profiling at infinity will overcorrect close shots, so it becomes important to either calibrate at multiple distances or just calibrate for the *least* case, and let infinity still have some vignetting (in-camera correction seems to do something like this). It's a messy situation... thanks for making the effort.
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

posts.author: maciejpatelczyk
posts.text:
Your suspicions were correct. At minimum focus distance applied vignetting correction reveals artificially increased luminance of the corners. It doesn't seem right. It's subtle at the beginning but when post-processing the image (increase exposure, adding contrast) it becomes more and more visible.

I can wait for next full overcast sky and do the same procedure with acrylic milk glass but changing the focus distance. So I will set focus to minimum and shoot with full spectrum of aperture. Then repeat this for the next focus distance. Does the change in aperture change the focus point? (not sure about it)

Would this be acceptable? How many focus distance I would need?
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text:
Well, considering that the acrylic-on-lens method can also possibly be a source of overcorrection, regardless of focus distance, I would say first try just doing the calibration at minimum focus distance. If applying this correction to shots at infinity produces something similar to in-camera correction, then I would say this is the "safe and simple" approach.

Otherwise, the best distances may depend on the lens. Torsten Bronger's tutorial suggests doubling the MFD once or twice, but some of the lenses we're talking about have very small MFD, so that might not apply as much... it might require some experimenting to see where in the range most of the change takes place. I'll try to do some tests related to this later today.
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text: Oh, and one other important thing is to disable image stabilisation for calibration/testing shots, since it can move the image circle off-center. (Yes, this means that pictures taken with stabilisation are sometimes not perfectly corrected - another reason it may be advisable to err on the side of under-correcting.)
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

posts.author: maciejpatelczyk
posts.text:
Right. This is the one thing I completly forgot.
One more question. If I intend to do the measurements for various focus distances does it mean that I could stand in one place and change simply the focus distance having image more or less blurred (as for initial measurement focused on infinity)?
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text: Yes, you don't actually *want* any "detail" in the calibration images, and don't need it for evaluation images.
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

posts.author: maciejpatelczyk
posts.text:
Right, so this is the second approach. Unfortunatelly this is done using acylic glass with heavy overcast sky. Can't figure out anything better than that in my environment. I have checked it agaist several pictures and did not observe any overcorrection. My 20mm closeups of flowers look good.
Measurements are for: minimum focus discance - 0.2m , 0.4m, 1.2m and inf. 0.4m is like 33% of scale and 1.2m is near inf (like 75%) for both lenses. Full range of the aperture values are covered.
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text: Thanks for doing the extra work! I'll add the data to the database shortly.
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text: - **status**: open --> implemented
posts.subject: #148 Calibration data for Panasonic Summilux 15mm f/1.7 and Lumix G 20mm f/1.7 II (vignetting only)

tickets.summary: Sigma 17-50mm F2.8 EX DC OS HSM (Vignetting)
tickets.description: I created the following vignette correction data for the Sigma 17-50mm F2.8 EX DC OS HSM Lens. Since it is a zoom lens and i did three pictures for each setting, the raw data set is 1,5GBs. Probably to large for a web upload i believe. Let me know how to best handle this.. I attached the calibration results. Measurements done with a Canon 550D.

posts.author: bronger
posts.text: My Internet connection can do this in less than three minutes.  But the same applies as in the other feature request:  The dots in the plot must not be too scattered.  Sorry that I cannot describe it better.  It is about the smoothness of the diffusor and its illumination.  If it is too small, the error of the measurement is too big.

tickets.summary: FF distortion data for an Opteka 15mm f/4 1:1 (Laowa clone)
tickets.description:
I was able to produce distortion data by following the Hugin tutorial on Vimeo, for an Opteka 15mm f/4 1:1, for the full frame format.
This lens does not transmit any exif data. It does not even have an aperture lever, it is preset, and the f/stops are unclicked and approximate.
I calibrated it on a Sony A7ii with a Nikon to e-mount adapter.
The distortion is uglily mustache-shaped at infinity. The calibration data I got corrects it.
This lens seems to be a clone of the Venus Laowa 15mm f/4 1:1, without the shifting mechanism.
Actually many variants or rebranded copies can be found on the web, looking more or less the same:
* Opteka 15mm f/4 LD UNC AL 1:1 Macro (mine)
* Venus Laowa 15 mm f/4 1:1 Macro
* Jintu 15mm F4 1:1 Wide Angle Macro
* Yunchenghe 15 mm f/4.0 1:1 
* Lightdow 15mm F/4 1:1 Macro
Apart from the look and the speficications, the Opteka and the Laowa show a similar mustache-shaped distortion. But I cannot guarantee at 100% that this is the same lens and I don't have a Laowa to test. I haven't seen samples for the others. Providing a 1:1 macro at 15mm is odd enough (for shooting stuffed insects?), this points towards the reuse of the same design.

Here is the calibration data for distortion :

<lensdatabase>

    <lens>
        <maker>Opteka</maker>
        <model>Opteka 15mm F4</model>
        <mount>Nikon F</mount>
        <cropfactor>1</cropfactor>
        <calibration>
            <distortion model="ptlens" focal="0" a="0.05114" b="-0.13551" c="0.04398"/>
        </calibration>
    </lens>

</lensdatabase>

Thanks
Patrice

posts.author: junkyardsparkle
posts.text: - **status**: open --> implemented
posts.subject: #116 FF distortion data for an Opteka 15mm f/4 1:1 (Laowa clone)

tickets.description:
Hi, 

I made the calibration below for the Tamron SP 35mm f/1.8 Di VC USD F012 to correct for barrel distorion. I used a full frame Nikon D810 camera. I checked the effect by editing my RawTherapee 5.4 lensfun database. I hope you will find that useful to incorporate into your permanent database. In case of questions, please don't hesitate to contact me. Best wishes,

Christian


	<lens>
		<maker>Tamron</maker>
		<model>Tamron SP 35mm f/1.8 Di VC USD F012</model>
		<mount>Canon EF</mount>
		<mount>Nikon F AF</mount>
		<mount>Sony Alpha</mount>
		<cropfactor>1.0</cropfactor>
		<calibration>
			<distortion model="poly3" focal="35" k1="-0.005" />
		</calibration>
	</lens>

tickets.description:
Hello,

please add support for Sony Alpha a68

    <camera>
        <maker>Sony</maker>
        <model>ILCA-68</model>
        <model lang="en">Alpha 68</model>
        <mount>Sony Alpha</mount>
    </camera>

    
How does one determine the crop factor? I suppose it is the same as the other Sony Alpha APS-C cameras, but I see 1.523, 1.528 and 1.534 being used.

posts.author: kiekerjan
posts.text:
I found the camera declaration description. Crop factor is "the ratio between the standard film frame diagonal (36x24mm) and camera sensor diagonal" (http://lensfun.sourceforge.net/manual/el_camera.html)
According to the manual, the sensor is 23.5 x 15.6 mm. This gives me a crop factor of 1.534, and thus

    <camera>
        <maker>Sony</maker>
        <model>ILCA-68</model>
        <model lang="en">Alpha 68</model>
        <mount>Sony Alpha</mount>
        <cropfactor>1.534</cropfactor>
    </camera>
posts.subject: #94 support for sony a68

posts.author: bronger
posts.text:
- **status**: open --> implemented
- **assigned_to**: Torsten Bronger
posts.subject: #94 support for sony a68
